articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Issues Recall Over Hacking
articles.snippet: The news that two researchers had hacked into a Jeep Cherokee, set in motion a nine-day flurry of activity by the automaker and the safety agency that culminated in the recall of 1.4 million vehicles.
articles.abstract: The news that two researchers had hacked into a Jeep Cherokee, set in motion a nine-day flurry of activity by the automaker and the safety agency that culminated in the recall of 1.4 million vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the call came to officials at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, they knew they had a problem they had never faced but had long feared.

articles.headline: Gap Widening as Top Workers Reap the Raises
articles.snippet: For most American workers, including many college graduates, the economic recovery has not meant significantly higher wages, research shows.
articles.abstract: For most American workers, including many college graduates, the economic recovery has not meant significantly higher wages, research shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The same scene plays out in Robert DeMeola’s Midtown Manhattan office every few weeks now — not that it ever gets any easier. In walks a director or senior accountant, job offer in hand, threatening to leave for a hedge fund or big bank unless Mr. DeMeola can deliver a raise of 30 percent, sometimes more.

articles.headline: New Drug Sharply Lowers Cholesterol, but It’s Costly
articles.snippet: The drug, Praluent, developed by Sanofi and Regeneron, is expected to become the next flashpoint in the growing controversy of escalating pharmaceutical price.
articles.abstract: The drug, Praluent, developed by Sanofi and Regeneron, is expected to become the next flashpoint in the growing controversy of escalating pharmaceutical price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Friday approved the first of a new class of drug that can sharply lower cholesterol levels, offering a new option for millions of Americans suffering from cardiovascular disease, the nation’s leading killer.

articles.headline: Fidelity Seen as Muscling Investors Out of Upside in a Telecom Deal
articles.snippet: The asset management giant’s plans to buy the Colt Group is angering minority shareholders who feel forced to sell at a bargain-basement price.
articles.abstract: The asset management giant’s plans to buy the Colt Group is angering minority shareholders who feel forced to sell at a bargain-basement price.
articles.lead_paragraph: As steward of a $5.2 trillion mutual fund and asset management empire, Fidelity Management and Research promises to treat investors fairly and put their interests first.

articles.headline: Municipal Bonds Still Considered Safe, Despite Some Ailing Governments
articles.snippet: Despite problems in places like Puerto Rico, default levels remain very low and are not expected to rise much, experts say, largely because governments can raise taxes.
articles.abstract: Despite problems in places like Puerto Rico, default levels remain very low and are not expected to rise much, experts say, largely because governments can raise taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico is drowning in $72 billion of debt it admittedly cannot pay back. Several states — Illinois, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Kentucky among them — are facing mounting financial problems of their own, mainly because of pension promises that are not properly funded.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Said to Contain Classified Data
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton pledged accountability as investigators cited four emails from the personal email account she used as secretary of state.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton pledged accountability as investigators cited four emails from the personal email account she used as secretary of state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Government investigators said Friday that they had discovered classified information on the private email account that Hillary Rodham Clinton used while secretary of state, stating unequivocally that those secrets never should have been stored outside of secure government computer systems.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Square’s Filing Turns Talk to Dorsey’s Juggling Skills
articles.snippet: The confidential filing allows the mobile payments start-up, which has expanded its ambitions, to keep the offering paperwork private until it is ready to seek investors.
articles.abstract: The confidential filing allows the mobile payments start-up, which has expanded its ambitions, to keep the offering paperwork private until it is ready to seek investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe Jack Dorsey needs to clone himself.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: U.S. Fears Data Stolen by Chinese Hacker Could Identify Spies
articles.snippet: The potential exposure of the American intelligence officers could prevent a large number of them from being posted abroad again.
articles.abstract: The potential exposure of the American intelligence officers could prevent a large number of them from being posted abroad again.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials are concerned that the Chinese government could use the stolen records of millions of federal workers and contractors to piece together the identities of intelligence officers secretly posted in China over the years.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Pakistan, Detainees Are Vanishing in Covert Jails
articles.snippet: Dozens have died in military detention amid accounts of torture, starvation and extrajudicial execution from ex-captives, relatives and rights monitors.
articles.abstract: Dozens have died in military detention amid accounts of torture, starvation and extrajudicial execution from ex-captives, relatives and rights monitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOHAT, Pakistan — Niaz Bibi’s son disappeared into the night, whisked away by Pakistani soldiers who accused him of being a Taliban fighter. For 18 anguishing months, she could find no word of his fate. Then she got a phone call.
articles.byline: By Taha Siddiqui and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: How Sorry Saved the Family Business
articles.snippet: After George Hincapie admitted to doping during his cycling career, he and his brother rescued their sportswear business by asking for forgiveness.
articles.abstract: After George Hincapie admitted to doping during his cycling career, he and his brother rescued their sportswear business by asking for forgiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mood was uncharacteristically somber in the conference room of Hincapie Sportswear as George Hincapie prepared to speak at an all-company meeting on Oct. 9, 2012.

articles.headline: For Ransom, Bitcoin Replaces the Bag of Bills
articles.snippet: These days, there’s a new preferred method for hostage takers: the virtual currency Bitcoin.
articles.abstract: These days, there’s a new preferred method for hostage takers: the virtual currency Bitcoin.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the old days, criminals liked their ransom payments in briefcases full of unmarked bills.

articles.headline: Presidential Race Just Started? Not According to the Spending
articles.snippet: Though most of the presidential candidates have been testing early primary states for months, the costs were not counted as campaign money until just recently, raising accounting and regulatory questions.
articles.abstract: Though most of the presidential candidates have been testing early primary states for months, the costs were not counted as campaign money until just recently, raising accounting and regulatory questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since late last year, presidential hopefuls have been romancing donors, hiring staff and haunting the diners and senior centers of Manchester and Dubuque.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Sarah Cohen and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Netflix Refines Its DVD Business, Even as Streaming Unit Booms
articles.snippet: Instead of ignoring its DVD-by-mail operation that was dwindling but still bringing in hundreds of millions of dollars in profits every year, the company concentrated on efficiency.
articles.abstract: Instead of ignoring its DVD-by-mail operation that was dwindling but still bringing in hundreds of millions of dollars in profits every year, the company concentrated on efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — It was just past sunrise on an early-spring morning at Netflix’s DVD operations here, where metallic arms whirred in a giant glass box and rolling carts holding millions of DVDs lined the walls. The company’s iconic red envelopes buzzed through an assembly line at the other end of the warehouse.

articles.headline: Fiat Chrysler Gets Record $105 Million Fine for Safety Issues
articles.snippet: Federal regulators on Sunday levied a record penalty against Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for failing to complete 23 safety recalls covering more than 11 million vehicles.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators on Sunday levied a record penalty against Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for failing to complete 23 safety recalls covering more than 11 million vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In their most aggressive crackdown yet on auto safety, federal regulators on Sunday levied a record penalty of $105 million against Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for failing to complete 23 safety recalls covering more than 11 million vehicles.

articles.headline: Senate Resurrection of Export-Import Bank Goes to Divided House
articles.snippet: House Republicans are split over the agency, whose authorization expired June 30 and which had stopped assistance to customers of American exports.
articles.abstract: House Republicans are split over the agency, whose authorization expired June 30 and which had stopped assistance to customers of American exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare and fiery weekend session, the Senate voted on Sunday to resurrect the federal Export-Import Bank, handing the Republican Party’s most conservative wing a major defeat and setting up a showdown this week with House leaders divided over the moribund export credit agency.

articles.headline: Texas County’s Racial Past Is Seen as Prelude to Sandra Bland’s Death
articles.snippet: The area where Ms. Bland graduated from college, returned for a job and later died has joined a list of places in America where assumptions of racial progress have been upended.
articles.abstract: The area where Ms. Bland graduated from college, returned for a job and later died has joined a list of places in America where assumptions of racial progress have been upended.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAIRIE VIEW, Tex. — When Sandra Bland enrolled in 2005 at Prairie View A&M University, the historically black institution founded here almost 140 years ago, its students were still waging a civil rights war that had ended elsewhere decades before: a legal battle, against white Waller County officials, for the right to vote in the place they lived.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and David Montgomery

articles.headline: Ads for Podcasts Test the Line Between Story and Sponsor
articles.snippet: Podcast networks like Gimlet Media and Panoply are increasingly relying on a funding model that asks reporters and hosts to help create ads or endorse advertisers’ products.
articles.abstract: Podcast networks like Gimlet Media and Panoply are increasingly relying on a funding model that asks reporters and hosts to help create ads or endorse advertisers’ products.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last several months, Lisa Chow, a reporter for and co-host of “StartUp,” a podcast about starting a business, has been interviewing engineers at Ford Motor.

articles.headline: Deregulator of Banks Set to Testify Before House
articles.snippet: Phil Gramm, one of the chief architects of a sweeping deregulation of financial rules in the late 1990s, will testify before the House Financial Services Committee on the impact of Dodd-Frank.
articles.abstract: Phil Gramm, one of the chief architects of a sweeping deregulation of financial rules in the late 1990s, will testify before the House Financial Services Committee on the impact of Dodd-Frank.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the House Financial Services Committee examines the sweeping overhaul of financial regulation on its fifth anniversary, legislators will first hear on Tuesday from a former senator with longstanding familiarity with banking regulations.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Republicans Alter Script on Abortion, Seeking to Shift Debate
articles.snippet: Republican politicians have refined the way they are talking about pregnancy and abortion rights, crafting their words in a way they hope puts Democrats on the defensive.
articles.abstract: Republican politicians have refined the way they are talking about pregnancy and abortion rights, crafting their words in a way they hope puts Democrats on the defensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rick Perry’s voice softens when he talks about the joy he gets from looking at his iPad and seeing “that 20-week picture of my first grandbaby.” Marco Rubio says ultrasounds of his sons and daughters reinforced how “they were children — and they were our children.” Rand Paul recalls watching fetuses suck their thumbs. And Chris Christie says the ultrasound of his first daughter changed his views on abortion.

articles.headline: Raising Floor for Minimum Wage Pushes Economy Into the Unknown
articles.snippet: Researchers have little experience with raises of such magnitude. The effects, especially in areas with low median incomes, could be profound.
articles.abstract: Researchers have little experience with raises of such magnitude. The effects, especially in areas with low median incomes, could be profound.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fight for a $15 minimum wage has gained momentum in New York, California and other places around the country in recent months. But as a national strategy to raise incomes at the bottom of the pay scale, it faces major obstacles, both political and economic.

articles.headline: ‘Sea Slaves’: The Human Misery That Feeds Pets and Livestock
articles.snippet: Men who have fled servitude on fishing boats recount beatings and worse as nets are cast for the catch that will become pet food and livestock feed.
articles.abstract: Men who have fled servitude on fishing boats recount beatings and worse as nets are cast for the catch that will become pet food and livestock feed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SONGKHLA, Thailand — Lang Long’s ordeal began in the back of a truck. After watching his younger siblings go hungry because their family’s rice patch in Cambodia could not provide for everyone, he accepted a trafficker’s offer to travel across the Thai border for a construction job.

articles.headline: More Fees Propel Airlines’ Profits, and Embitter Travelers
articles.snippet: Bag fees, flight-change fees, special seat requests, first-class upgrades: Profit margins for nonticket add-ons can be as high as 80 percent, says one analyst.
articles.abstract: Bag fees, flight-change fees, special seat requests, first-class upgrades: Profit margins for nonticket add-ons can be as high as 80 percent, says one analyst.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a frequent business traveler, Wayne Miller, a distributor for an ethnic foods company, often pays extra to stretch out his legs. When he paid $38 for a window seat with extra legroom on a recent cross-country flight, though, Mr. Miller was upset to find out, when he boarded, that the seat didn’t actually have window access.

articles.headline: Greece Made Preparations to Exit Euro
articles.snippet: The contingency plans for a possible exit from the euro began before the current leaders came to power, the former Greek finance minister said.
articles.abstract: The contingency plans for a possible exit from the euro began before the current leaders came to power, the former Greek finance minister said.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Already struggling with internal conflict, Greece’s government is facing new criticism over secret preparations that would have allowed the country to leave the euro if necessary.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Niki Kitsantonis
